3-Component balance




Apparatus

Load Cell

A load cell is a transducer that is used to convert a force into electrical signal.A load cell is generally comprised of three parts: a mechanical system, a strain gauge,and electronic amplification device.The measurement of a force is done by the use of these three parts in order they are listed. It should be noted that load cells can be configured with multiple strain gauges.

Measuring Force,Step1

First,a force is applied to the mechanical system,which transfers the force to strain gauge,which is basically an elastic foil connected to a wheatstone bridge configuration. This wheatstone bridge configuration is the electronic device that the strain gauge uses to convert a certain amount of strain into electrical output. Essentially,the mechanical system and strain gauge are used to convert a force into electrical output.

Measuring Force,Step2

This electrical output is generally very small,so it is amplified using a form of electric amplification,for which an integrated circuit or transistor may possibly be used.The electrical output is measured and then plugged into computer algorithm.The algorithm uses the amount of electricity to tell a user how much force was applied to load cell.

Strain gage


GF=ΔR/RG/ε
GF= gage factor

Wheatstone bridge


Procedure

Calibration Procedure:

  1. Known dead weights were applied in steps i.e 1000 g,1000 g,250 g for lift,drag and pitching moment respectively
  2. Readings indicated by the indicator for all three components was noted for each load.
  3. The observed data was plotted against the actual load.
  4. The slope of the curves obtained and the variation in the observations was noted.

INFERENCES:

  1. For the Lift Loading
    • Lift observed is a linear graph with slope1
    • PM is a constant
    • Drag variation is negligible
  2. For Drag Loading
    • Lift variation is negligible
    • PM variation is negligible
    • Drag observed is a linear graph with slope approximately 1
  3. For the PM Loading
    • Lift observed is a linear graph with slope 12.5(approx.)
    • PM variation is a linear graph with slope 1
    • Drag variation is negligible
